title: 103_s493
content: The "Hospital Cooperative Agreement Act" aims to promote collaboration among hospitals to reduce costs and enhance efficiency in healthcare delivery by sharing technology and services through a demonstration program. The Secretary will establish a demonstration program awarding grants to hospitals for collaboration on expensive medical technology. Eligible applicants must be hospitals willing to enter into cooperative agreements with other hospitals in the same state or region. The Secretary will award grants to hospitals for collaboration on medical technology through cooperative agreements with other hospitals in the same state or region. The Administrator will develop evaluation guidelines for applications, and the Secretary will evaluate and approve applications for grant awards. The Secretary will consider applications for grants based on guidelines for collaboration among hospitals to enhance care quality, preserve facilities, improve cost-effectiveness, resource utilization, and avoid duplication. Grant funds are to be used solely for promoting hospital collaboration, not for purchasing. The grants awarded under this section are to facilitate collaboration among hospitals for specialized personnel, administrative services, support services, and instructional programs. Additionally, at least three grants must demonstrate how cooperative agreements can improve access to care in rural areas. Medical technology and services sharing among hospitals is also a key aspect of these cooperative agreements. The section allows hospitals to share medical or high technology equipment/services. Medical technology includes drugs, devices, and procedures. Eligible services must have high costs and shared ownership can reduce excess capacity. Mobile clinic services may be included. The demonstration program allows hospitals to enter into cooperative agreements for 5 years to reduce healthcare costs, increase access to medical services, and improve healthcare quality. A report will be submitted to Congress after 5 years with recommendations for future programs. Antitrust laws do not apply to hospitals entering into cooperative agreements under this section. Antitrust laws do not apply to hospitals entering into cooperative agreements under this section, as defined by the Sherman Act, Federal Trade Commission Act, Clayton Act, and State antitrust laws. Antitrust laws do not apply to hospitals entering into cooperative agreements under this section, as defined by the Sherman Act, Federal Trade Commission Act, Clayton Act, and State antitrust laws. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 1994 through 1998.
